@spidr OpenGL tutorials are good for learning how things WORK (I learned a lot from here: http://nehe.gamedev.net/), but I always suggest using VTK so that people can concentrate on their higher level work (i.e. they just want the sphere to represent a position (a marker) - they don't care how the vertices of the sphere are ordered, etc) and VTK takes care of all of these low level details.

@pwang, I think the latter sounds great.  Feel free to bring in specific examples from chaco or elsewhere. As you mention, a survey would be hard to do right.

Since visualization is such a huge topic, we have to have better focus on a few high-level topics and then drill down into those.  If we chose to do an overview of existing toolkits, I worry that the scope is too large to cover in a single episode.  There's everything from ggplot to Paraview, not to mention commercial offerings like Tecplot.  Even if we just talked about programmer toolkits, I think it would be difficult to do it justice in a single episode.
I have seen Processing used to great effect for "infographics" or algorithmic art, but I haven't seen it used too much for building effective data graphics...
It sits quite nicely between throwing things to matplotlib or the like, and having to go all out with OpenGL -- shines especially when you want your scientific visualization to be interactive.
